awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: INteractive VIsualization and PracTice basEd Cybersecurity Curriculum and Training (InviteCyber) Framework for Developing Next-gen Cyber-Aware Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Technology use among teenagers has greatly increased without a concomitant increase cybersecurity skills in this population. Several factors, including lack of standard high school cybersecurity curricula, and lack of cybersecurity awareness among teens, have contributed to teenagers becoming targets of cybercrimes such as cyberbullying. This research aims to leverage the increased technology use of teens to (a) develop a security mindset at the high school level, (b) spread awareness of the risks and threats associated with use of smartphone/tablets and other tech, and (c) inculcate interest in cybersecurity careers (with a long-term goal of addressing the national shortage of cybersecurity workforce). The project seeks to achieve these goals by providing cybersecurity training through interactive, animated visualizations so that students develop an interest in cybersecurity careers. Educators will have access to the educational materials developed which may lead to the better assessment of students' cybersecurity skills. This new interactive animated visualization framework for high school cybersecurity education has the potential for wider, nationwide adoption. As cybersecurity continues to become a national and global security threat, this research will facilitate the development of a new generation of workforce and a safer cyber-environment.

The project will develop an innovative teaching plan and pedagogical methods for high school cybersecurity education. The framework will be designed and used in a summer camp setting to help students understand cybersecurity threats, defense, and prevention mechanisms. Open-source smartphone app development tools will be integrated into the curriculum to determine if the framework aids teens in understanding the cybersecurity risks. A series of research questions will investigate the extent to which the "new" curriculum promotes a better understanding of cybersecurity. The effectiveness and rigor of this curriculum will be measured in several ways, including (a) using a task load index to quantify rigor, (b) administering surveys to gain insight about students' motivation and perceptions of cybersecurity, and (c) analyzing students' learning using analytical course rubrics. Deliverables of this project will involve (a) interactive animated visualization based cybersecurity tutorials for summer camp mode delivery to high school students, (b) availability of all tutorials for accessibility to other educators, and (c) publications and meeting presentations to share project outcomes more widely.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

InviteCyber was a 5-year (with a second NCE) Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Education (EDU) collaborative project between the University of Toledo, Purdue University Northwest, and Fairfield University. The project sought to develop a security mindset at the high school level and encourage students to pursue careers in cybersecurity and be prepared to combat future cyber warfare. The project was driven by the critical role of cybersecurity across all domains and the challenge that there was a huge lack of workforce trained in cybersecurity. Its goal was to instill a security mindset at the high-school level, spread awareness of the risks and threats associated with the usage of smartphones/tablets among teenagers, and encourage them to pursue careers in cybersecurity and prepare for future cyber threats.

Project Goal

The overarching goal of InviteCyber was to provide efficient cybersecurity training and develop a cybersecurity curriculum for high school students through interactive animated visualization. By the conclusion of the project, we expect to deliver a high school cybersecurity curriculum prototype that has been tested in a summer camp setting several times. Most of the activities that were expected to be completed within the reporting period are complete. 

1. Develop a security mindset at the high school level.
2. Spread awareness of the risks and threats associated with the usage of smartphones/tablets.
3. Inculcate interest in cybersecurity careers (with a long-term goal of addressing the national shortage of cybersecurity skills).

 Broader Impacts

InviteCyber had broader impacts in terms of generation of a new, ubiquitous interactive animation visualization for high school cybersecurity education. Beyond presentations and publications, the work will be disseminated through the release of open source software and “fake” mobile applications that can be used for instruction. Additionally, the use of smartphone app development & visualization, and interactive visualization in high school education has the potential to transform teaching and learning. This may be a better way to recruit the next generation of learners who are more tech-savvy compared to instructors, into STEM disciplines. At multiple institutions, including Purdue University Northwest (PNW), the University of Toledo (UToledo), and Fairfield University (FairfieldU) both undergraduate and graduate students were involved in creating and delivering content for the summer camps. These materials were tested and refined over the project’s five-year duration and made available on a website for widespread use. The project’s findings were shared through conferences, and online platforms, with instructional manuals provided for free distribution to enhance cybersecurity education across various institutions.

Project Outcomes. InviteCyber resulted in the following outcomes.

1. Mentoring of graduate and undergraduate research assistants in presentation and pedagogical techniques.
2. Training and development of faculty members involved in the project.
3. Developed modules were found to positively affect cybersecurity learning and perception of the students both at the high school and college freshmen levels.
4. Various lecture materials were prepared to introduce students to important topics in cybersecurity:

  • Intro to Cybersecurity
  • Android Development
  • Cryptography
  • Cyber-safe Practices and Cyber Hygiene
  • Malware
  • Responsible AI
  • Internet
  • Internet Security
  • Web Security

5. A website for disseminating information about the project and to make modules available to both professional developers and high school teachers (https://sites.google.com/pnw.edu/invitecyber).

6. At the end of the project, results of the following evaluation questions (or RQs) were affirmative:

  • Does student perception of cybersecurity concepts improve?
  • Does student ability of cybersecurity problem-solving improve?
  • Are students more interested in cybersecurity after the summer camp?
  • Are interactive animated visualization modules effective in supporting learning of the physical, software, and mathematical aspects of cyber security?
  • Do smartphone based interactive learning modules improve students’ problem-solving ability to resolve real-world cyber security related issues such as malware or phishing attacks?


 


Last Modified: 11/28/2024
Modified by: Xiaoli Yang

Image
  • InviteCyber framework
    None
    Public Domain
    Xiaoli Yang
    InviteCyber

Overview


InviteCyber was a 5-year (with a second NCE) Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Education (EDU) collaborative project between the University of Toledo, Purdue University Northwest, and Fairfield University. The project sought to develop a security mindset at the high school level and encourage students to pursue careers in cybersecurity and be prepared to combat future cyber warfare. The project was driven by the critical role of cybersecurity across all domains and the challenge that there was a huge lack of workforce trained in cybersecurity. Its goal was to instill a security mindset at the high-school level, spread awareness of the risks and threats associated with the usage of smartphones/tablets among teenagers, and encourage them to pursue careers in cybersecurity and prepare for future cyber threats.


Project Goal


The overarching goal of InviteCyber was to provide efficient cybersecurity training and develop a cybersecurity curriculum for high school students through interactive animated visualization. By the conclusion of the project, we expect to deliver a high school cybersecurity curriculum prototype that has been tested in a summer camp setting several times. Most of the activities that were expected to be completed within the reporting period are complete.


1. Develop a security mindset at the high school level.
2. Spread awareness of the risks and threats associated with the usage of smartphones/tablets.
3. Inculcate interest in cybersecurity careers (with a long-term goal of addressing the national shortage of cybersecurity skills).

InviteCyber had broader impacts in terms of generation of a new, ubiquitous interactive animation visualization for high school cybersecurity education. Beyond presentations and publications, the work will be disseminated through the release of open source software and fake mobile applications that can be used for instruction. Additionally, the use of smartphone app development & visualization, and interactive visualization in high school education has the potential to transform teaching and learning. This may be a better way to recruit the next generation of learners who are more tech-savvy compared to instructors, into STEM disciplines. At multiple institutions, including Purdue University Northwest (PNW), the University of Toledo (UToledo), and Fairfield University (FairfieldU) both undergraduate and graduate students were involved in creating and delivering content for the summer camps. These materials were tested and refined over the projects five-year duration and made available on a website for widespread use. The projects findings were shared through conferences, and online platforms, with instructional manuals provided for free distribution to enhance cybersecurity education across various institutions.


Project Outcomes. InviteCyber resulted in the following outcomes.


1. Mentoring of graduate and undergraduate research assistants in presentation and pedagogical techniques.
2. Training and development of faculty members involved in the project.
3. Developed modules were found to positively affect cybersecurity learning and perception of the students both at the high school and college freshmen levels.
4. Various lecture materials were prepared to introduce students to important topics in cybersecurity:

Intro to Cybersecurity
Android Development
Cryptography
Cyber-safe Practices and Cyber Hygiene
Malware
Responsible AI
Internet
Internet Security
Web Security



5. A website for disseminating information about the project and to make modules available to both professional developers and high school teachers (https://sites.google.com/pnw.edu/invitecyber).


6. At the end of the project, results of the following evaluation questions (or RQs) were affirmative:

Does student perception of cybersecurity concepts improve?
Does student ability of cybersecurity problem-solving improve?
Are students more interested in cybersecurity after the summer camp?
Are interactive animated visualization modules effective in supporting learning of the physical, software, and mathematical aspects of cyber security?
Do smartphone based interactive learning modules improve students problem-solving ability to resolve real-world cyber security related issues such as malware or phishing attacks?
